body:
Comment 5: 
1. a = f(b)  -- looks like a function taking an argument and returning a result
2. f(b)  -- looks like a function taking an argument and doing something
3. f(&b) -- looks like a function taking an argument and doing something with
potentially modifying b

I think that the 3. style would be much more appropriate than 1, but 2. would be more
convenient.

"append" being destructive on the arguments was very surprising to me, although at some
point I probably read documentation (not very carefully). With maps it was more visible
since "a[b] = c" looks like you are modifying something and then you have a question of
atomicity.

I think some people may stumble upon this problem again. If you think there's no need to
modify func declaration/documentation it's ok, maybe they can find this issue thread
instead.
